title: 108_hr1800
content: The policy of the United States is to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by prohibiting their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. Prohibited acts and penalties are outlined in the legislation. It is illegal to import, export, or transport fur or steel-jawed leghold traps across state lines if they are derived from animals trapped in such traps. Violators will face penalties, including imprisonment for repeat offenses. For the first violation, the penalty is up to 5 days in prison or a fine under title 18, United States Code. Subsequent violations may result in up to 2 years in prison or a fine under title 18, United States Code. SEC. 3. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to anyone providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Exceptions apply to government officials. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces this Act and its rules, utilizing personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import and export violations are treated as customs law violations, with penalties enforced under the Export Administration Act of 1979. Enforcement authorities can detain, search, and seize packages suspected of containing articles violating the Act. They can also make warrantless arrests for Act violations. Enforcement authorities have the power to detain, search, and seize packages suspected of violating the Act. They can also make warrantless arrests for Act violations and execute warrants issued by judges or magistrates. Additionally, forfeiture rules apply to articles of fur or conventional steel-jawed leghold traps. Any article of fur or conventional steel-jawed leghold trap found in violation of the Act will be subject to forfeiture to the United States. Seizure, forfeiture, and disposition rules similar to customs laws apply to such cases. Under this subsection, the Secretary or authorized officers may enforce property seizures and forfeitures similar to customs laws. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators of the Act. Cooperation is required from the Secretary of Commerce and other relevant agencies. Cooperation is required from the Secretary of Commerce, the Secretary of the Treasury, and other relevant agencies to ensure effective enforcement of this Act and its rules. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" refers to furskins or articles made from furskins. The term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" describes a specific type of trap designed to capture animals. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to any law or regulation enforced by customs authorities. The term "import" refers to bringing goods into the United States, while "interstate commerce" is defined in title 18 of the United States Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior may make rules to implement the Act, which will take effect one year after its enactment.
